notes: On 13 March 2020, Breonna Taylor, a Black emergency room technician, was shot and killed by Louisville police in Louisville (Kentucky) when officers raided her apartment during a no-knock raid. Police opened fire after her boyfriend fired his gun, which he legally possessed, hitting one of the officers, thinking the police were intruders breaking into the home. The police were conducting a raid after a search warrant was issued based on an affidavit from a detective who had been investigating Taylor's ex-boyfriend and claimed that he had information verified through a US postal inspector that her ex-boyfriend had received packages suspected to contain drugs at Taylor's apartment. The police claim that evidence, including a witness, indicated that the officers knocked and announced their presence while using a battering ram to enter the apartment. Taylor's boyfriend, her family, and their lawyers dispute these claims. The only witness now claiming that the officers did announce themselves previously told Louisville Metro Police investigators that the officers had not announced their presence. Eleven other residents have said that they did not hear the police announce themselves. A US postal inspector in Louisville told the media that city police did not use his office to verify the detective's information. Taylor's lawyers claim that the information provided by the detective was false and that 'no packages of interest' had been delivered to the address. No drugs were found in the apartment during the raid. On 23 September, one of the officers involved in the raid was indicted by a Kentucky grand jury with three counts of wanton endangerment for firing into Taylor's neighbors' homes during the raid. On 5 January 2021, two officers, one who fired 16 rounds into Taylor's home and the other who had written the search warrant, were fired by Louisville Metro Police Department.
